<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="-2.2-Reading-in-the-Survey-Data"><a name="2.2" /> 2.2 Reading in the Survey Data<a class="anchor-link" href="#-2.2-Reading-in-the-Survey-Data">¶</a></h3><p>We can make some observations based on the first few rows of each one.</p>
<ul>
<li>Each data set appears to either have a <code>DBN</code> column, or the information we need to create one. That means we can use a <code>DBN</code> column to combine the data sets. First we'll pinpoint matching rows from different data sets by looking for identical DBNs, then group all of their columns together in a single data set.</li>
<li>Some fields look interesting for mapping -- particularly <code>Location 1</code>, which contains coordinates inside a larger string.</li>
<li>Some of the data sets appear to contain multiple rows for each school (because the rows have duplicate <code>DBN</code> values). That means weâ€™ll have to do some preprocessing to ensure that each DBN is unique within each data set. If we don't do this, we'll run into problems when we combine the data sets, because we might be merging two rows in one data set with one row in another data set.</li>
</ul>
<p><br></p>
<p>Before we proceed with the merge, we should make sure we have all of the data we want to unify. We mentioned the survey data earlier (<code>survey_all.txt</code> and <code>survey_d75.txt</code>), but we didn't read those files in because they're in a slightly more complex format.</p>
<p><br></p>
<p>The files are tab delimited and encoded with <strong>Windows-1252</strong> encoding. An encoding defines how a computer stores the contents of a file in binary. The most common encodings are <strong>UTF-8</strong> and <strong>ASCII</strong>. Windows-1252 is rarely used, and can cause errors if we read such a file in without specifying the encoding.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [4]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">all_survey</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">read_csv</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Data/high_schools/survey_all.txt'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">delimiter</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="se">\t</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">encoding</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'windows-1252'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">d75_survey</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">read_csv</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Data/high_schools/survey_d75.txt'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">delimiter</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="se">\t</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">encoding</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'windows-1252'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">survey</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">concat</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">all_survey</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">d75_survey</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">axis</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">sort</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">survey</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">info</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">

memory usage: 36.0+ MB
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [5]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">survey</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[5]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>
<style scoped>
    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {
        vertical-align: middle;
    }

    .dataframe tbody tr th {
        vertical-align: top;
    }

    .dataframe thead th {
        text-align: right;
    }
</style>
<table border="1" class="dataframe">
  <thead>
    <tr style="text-align: right;">
      <th></th>
      <th>N_p</th>
      <th>N_s</th>
      <th>N_t</th>
      <th>aca_p_11</th>
      <th>aca_s_11</th>
      <th>aca_t_11</th>
      <th>aca_tot_11</th>
      <th>bn</th>
      <th>com_p_11</th>
      <th>com_s_11</th>
      <th>...</th>
      <th>t_q8c_1</th>
      <th>t_q8c_2</th>
      <th>t_q8c_3</th>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="-2.3-Cleaning-Up-the-Surveys"><a name="2.3" /> 2.3 Cleaning Up the Surveys<a class="anchor-link" href="#-2.3-Cleaning-Up-the-Surveys">¶</a></h3><p>There are two immediate facts that we can see in the data:</p>
<ul>
<li>There are over <code>2000</code> columns, nearly all of which we don't need. We'll have to filter the data to remove the unnecessary ones. Working with fewer columns will make it easier to print the dataframe out and find correlations within it.</li>
<li>The survey data has a <code>dbn</code> column that we'll want to convert to uppercase (<code>DBN</code>). The conversion will make the column name consistent with the other data sets.</li>
</ul>
<p>First, we'll need filter the columns to remove the ones we don't need. Luckily, there's a data dictionary at the original data download location. The dictionary tells us what each column represents. Based on our knowledge of the problem and the analysis we're trying to do, we can use the data dictionary to determine which columns to use.</p>
<p>Based on the dictionary, it looks like these are the relevant columns:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"dbn"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"rr_s"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"rr_t"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"rr_p"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"N_s"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"N_t"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"N_p"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"saf_p_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"com_p_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"eng_p_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"aca_p_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"saf_t_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"com_t_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"eng_t_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"aca_t_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"saf_s_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"com_s_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"eng_s_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"aca_s_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"saf_tot_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"com_tot_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"eng_tot_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"aca_tot_11"</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>
<p>These columns will give us aggregate survey data about how parents, teachers, and students feel about school safety, academic performance, and more. It will also give us the DBN, which allows us to uniquely identify the school.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [6]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">survey</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"DBN"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">survey</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"dbn"</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">survey</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">survey</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="s2">"DBN"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"rr_s"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"rr_t"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"rr_p"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"N_s"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"N_t"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"N_p"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"saf_p_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"com_p_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"eng_p_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"aca_p_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"saf_t_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"com_t_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"eng_t_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"aca_t_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"saf_s_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"com_s_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"eng_s_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"aca_s_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"saf_tot_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"com_tot_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"eng_tot_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"aca_tot_11"</span><span class="p">]]</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'survey'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">survey</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'survey'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">info</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p><br></p>
<h2 id="-3.-Preparing-Datasets-for-Merging"><a name="3" /> 3. Preparing Datasets for Merging<a class="anchor-link" href="#-3.-Preparing-Datasets-for-Merging">¶</a></h2><hr>
<p>When we explored all of the data sets, we noticed that some of them, like <code>class_size</code> don't have a DBN column. <code>hs_directory</code> does have a dbn column, though, so we can just rename it.</p>
<p>However, class_size doesn't appear to have the column at all.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [7]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'class_size'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>With a closer inspection of the datasets, we can tell that the <code>DBN</code> in the <code>sat_results</code> data is just a combination of the <code>CSD</code> and <code>SCHOOL CODE</code> columns in the <code>class_size</code> data. The main difference is that the DBN is padded, so that the CSD portion of it always consists of two digits. That means we'll need to add a leading 0 to the <code>CSD</code> if the <code>CSD</code> is less than two digits long.</p>
<p>We can accomplish this using the pandas <strong>pandas.DataFrame.apply()</strong> method, along with a custom function that:</p>
<ul>
<li>Takes in a number.</li>
<li>Converts the number to a string using the str() function.</li>
<li>Check the length of the string using the len() function.</li>
<li>If the string is two digits long, returns the string.</li>
<li>If the string is one digit long, adds a 0 to the front of the string, then returns it.</li>
</ul>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [10]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'hs_directory'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'DBN'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'hs_directory'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'dbn'</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">padding</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">row</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">string_rep</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">row</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="k">if</span> <span class="nb">len</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">string_rep</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">></span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">string_rep</span>
    <span class="k">else</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">string_rep</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">zfill</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'class_size'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'padded_csd'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'class_size'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'CSD'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">padding</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'class_size'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s2">"DBN"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'class_size'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s2">"padded_csd"</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'class_size'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s2">"SCHOOL CODE"</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'class_size'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s2">"DBN"</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[10]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>0    01M015
1    01M015
2    01M015
3    01M015
4    01M015
Name: DBN, dtype: object</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="-3.1-Convert-Columns-to-Numeric"><a name="3.1" /> 3.1 Convert Columns to Numeric<a class="anchor-link" href="#-3.1-Convert-Columns-to-Numeric">¶</a></h3><p>Now we're almost ready to combine our data sets. Before we do, let's take some time to calculate variables that will be useful in our analysis. We've already discussed one such variable -- a column that totals up the SAT scores for the different sections of the exam. This will make it much easier to correlate scores with demographic factors because we'll be working with a single number, rather than three different ones.</p>
<p>Before we can generate this column, we'll need to convert the <code>SAT Math Avg. Score</code>, <code>SAT Critical Reading Avg. Score</code>, and <code>SAT Writing Avg. Score</code> columns in the sat_results data set from the object (string) data type to a numeric data type. We can use the <strong>pandas.to_numeric()</strong> method for the conversion. If we don't convert the values, we won't be able to add the columns together.</p>
<p>It's important to pass the keyword argument <code>errors="coerce"</code> when we call <code>pandas.to_numeric()</code>, so that pandas treats any invalid strings it can't convert to numbers as missing values instead.</p>
<p>After we perform the conversion, we can use the addition operator (<code>+</code>) to add all three columns together.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [8]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sat_results'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'SAT Math Avg. Score'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_numeric</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sat_results'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'SAT Math Avg. Score'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">errors</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'coerce'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sat_results'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'SAT Critical Reading Avg. Score'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_numeric</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sat_results'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'SAT Critical Reading Avg. Score'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">errors</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'coerce'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sat_results'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'SAT Writing Avg. Score'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_numeric</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sat_results'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'SAT Writing Avg. Score'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">errors</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'coerce'</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sat_results'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'sat_score'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sat_results'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'SAT Math Avg. Score'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sat_results'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'SAT Critical Reading Avg. Score'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sat_results'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'SAT Writing Avg. Score'</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sat_results'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'sat_score'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[8]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>0    1122.0
1    1172.0
2    1149.0
3    1174.0
4    1207.0
Name: sat_score, dtype: float64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="-3.2-Parsing-Geographic-Coordinates-for-Schools"><a name="3.2" /> 3.2 Parsing Geographic Coordinates for Schools<a class="anchor-link" href="#-3.2-Parsing-Geographic-Coordinates-for-Schools">¶</a></h3><p>Next, we'll want to parse the latitude and longitude coordinates for each school. This will enable us to map the schools and uncover any geographic patterns in the data. The coordinates are currently in the text field <code>Location 1</code> in the <code>hs_directory</code> data set.</p>
<p>Let's take a look at the first few rows:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"hs_directory"</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'Location 1'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[9]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>0    883 Classon Avenue\nBrooklyn, NY 11225\n(40.67...
1    1110 Boston Road\nBronx, NY 10456\n(40.8276026...
2    1501 Jerome Avenue\nBronx, NY 10452\n(40.84241...
3    411 Pearl Street\nNew York, NY 10038\n(40.7106...
4    160 20 Goethals Avenue\nJamaica, NY 11432\n(40...
Name: Location 1, dtype: object</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>As you can see, this field contains a lot of information we don't need. We want to extract the coordinates, which are in parentheses at the end of the field. More specifically, we want to extract the latitude, <code>40.8276026690005</code>, and the longitude, <code>-73.90447525699966</code>. Taken together, latitude and longitude make up a pair of coordinates that allows us to pinpoint any location on Earth.</p>
<p><br></p>
<p>We can do the extraction with a regular expression. The following expression will pull out everything inside the parentheses:</p>
<div class="highlight"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">re</span>
<span class="n">re</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">findall</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"\(.+\)"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"1110 Boston Road</span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2">Bronx, NY 10456</span><span class="se">\n</span><span class="s2">(40.8276026690005, -73.90447525699966)"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>
<p>This command will return (<code>40.8276026690005</code>, <code>-73.90447525699966</code>). We'll need to process this result further using the string methods <code>split()</code> and <code>replace()</code> methods to extract each coordinate.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [11]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">get_lat</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">row</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">coords</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">re</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">findall</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"\(.+\)"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">row</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">coords</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">coords</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">replace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'('</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">''</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">coords</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">coords</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">replace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">')'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">''</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">coords</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">coords</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">','</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">coords</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
    
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'hs_directory'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'lat'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'hs_directory'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'Location 1'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">get_lat</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'hs_directory'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'lat'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[11]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>0     40.67029890700047
1      40.8276026690005
2    40.842414068000494
3     40.71067947100045
4    40.718810094000446
Name: lat, dtype: object</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>we have now parsed the <strong>latitude</strong> from the <code>Location 1</code> column. Now we'll just need to do the same for the <strong>longitude</strong>.</p>
<p>Once we have both coordinates, we'll need to convert them to numeric values. We can use the <code>pandas.to_numeric()</code> function to convert them from strings to numbers.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [12]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">get_lon</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">row</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">coords</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">re</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">findall</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"\(.+\)"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">row</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">coords</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">coords</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">replace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'('</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">''</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">coords</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">coords</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">replace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">')'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">''</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">coords</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">coords</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">split</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">','</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">coords</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span>
    
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'hs_directory'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'lon'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'hs_directory'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'Location 1'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">get_lon</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'hs_directory'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'lon'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_numeric</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'hs_directory'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'lon'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">errors</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'coerce'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'hs_directory'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'lat'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_numeric</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'hs_directory'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'lat'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">errors</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'coerce'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'hs_directory'</span><span class="p">][[</span><span class="s1">'lon'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'lat'</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">())</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>         lon        lat
0 -73.961648  40.670299
1 -73.904475  40.827603
2 -73.916162  40.842414
3 -74.000807  40.710679
4 -73.806500  40.718810
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="-4.-Combining-the-Data"><a name="4" /> 4. Combining the Data<a class="anchor-link" href="#-4.-Combining-the-Data">¶</a></h2><hr>
<p>The first thing we'll need to do in preparation for the merge is condense some of the data sets. In some of the previous steps, we noticed that the values in the <code>DBN</code> column were unique in the <code>sat_results</code> data set. Other data sets like <code>class_size</code> had duplicate <code>DBN</code> values, however.</p>
<p>We'll need to condense these data sets so that each value in the <code>DBN</code> column is unique. If not, we'll run into issues when it comes time to combine the data sets.</p>
<p>While the main data set we want to analyze, <code>sat_results</code>, has unique <code>DBN</code> values for every high school in New York City, other data sets aren't as clean. A single row in the <code>sat_results</code> data set may match multiple rows in the <code>class_size</code> data set, for example. This situation will create problems, because we don't know which of the multiple entries in the <code>class_size</code> data set we should combine with the single matching entry in <code>sat_results</code>.</p>
<p>To resolve this issue, we'll condense the <code>class_size</code>, <code>graduation</code>, and <code>demographics</code> data sets so that each <code>DBN</code> is unique.</p>
<h3 id="-4.1-Condensing-the-Class-Size-Data-Set"><a name="4.1" /> 4.1 Condensing the Class Size Data Set<a class="anchor-link" href="#-4.1-Condensing-the-Class-Size-Data-Set">¶</a></h3><p>The first data set that we'll condense is <code>class_size</code>. The first few rows of <code>class_size</code> look like this:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [13]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"class_size"</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[13]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">

</div>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>As you can see, the first few rows all pertain to the same school, which is why the <code>DBN</code> appears more than once. It looks like each school has multiple values for <code>GRADE</code>, <code>PROGRAM TYPE</code>, <code>CORE SUBJECT (MS CORE and 9-12 ONLY)</code>, and <code>CORE COURSE (MS CORE and 9-12 ONLY)</code>.</p>
<p>If we look at the unique values for GRADE, we get the following:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [16]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"class_size"</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'GRADE '</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[16]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>09-12      10644
MS Core     4762
0K-09       1384
0K          1237
01          1185

04          1140

Name: GRADE , dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Because we're dealing with high schools, we're only concerned with grades 9 through 12. That means we only want to pick rows where the value in the <code>GRADE</code> column is <code>09-12</code>.</p>
<p>If we look at the unique values for PROGRAM TYPE, we get the following:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [17]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"class_size"</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="s1">'PROGRAM TYPE'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[17]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>GEN ED     14545
CTT         7460
SPEC ED     3653
G&T          469
Name: PROGRAM TYPE, dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Each school can have multiple program types. Because <code>GEN ED</code> is the largest category by far, let's only select rows where <code>PROGRAM TYPE</code> is <code>GEN ED</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [18]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">class_size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'class_size'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">class_size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">class_size</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">class_size</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'GRADE '</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s1">'09-12'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">class_size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">class_size</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">class_size</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'PROGRAM TYPE'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s1">'GEN ED'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">class_size</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[18]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="-4.2-Computing-Average-Class-Sizes"><a name="4.2" /> 4.2 Computing Average Class Sizes<a class="anchor-link" href="#-4.2-Computing-Average-Class-Sizes">¶</a></h3><p>As we saw when we displayed class_size on the last screen, DBN still isn't completely unique. This is due to the <code>CORE COURSE (MS CORE and 9-12 ONLY)</code> and <code>CORE SUBJECT (MS CORE and 9-12 ONLY)</code> columns.</p>
<p><code>CORE COURSE (MS CORE and 9-12 ONLY)</code> and <code>CORE SUBJECT (MS CORE and 9-12 ONLY)</code> seem to pertain to different kinds of classes. For example, here are the unique values for <code>CORE SUBJECT (MS CORE and 9-12 ONLY)</code>:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [19]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">class_size</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'CORE SUBJECT (MS CORE and 9-12 ONLY)'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[19]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>ENGLISH           1977
SCIENCE           1636
SOCIAL STUDIES    1453
MATH              1447
Name: CORE SUBJECT (MS CORE and 9-12 ONLY), dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This column only seems to include certain subjects. We want our class size data to include every single class a school offers -- not just a subset of them. What we can do is take the average across all of the classes a school offers. This will give us unique DBN values, while also incorporating as much data as possible into the average.</p>
<p>Fortunately, we can use the <strong>pandas.DataFrame.groupby()</strong> method to help us with this. The DataFrame.groupby() method will split a dataframe up into unique groups, based on a given column. We can then use the <strong>agg()</strong> method on the resulting <code>pandas.core.groupby</code> object to find the mean of each column.</p>
<p><br></p>
<p>After we group a dataframe and aggregate data based on it, the column we performed the grouping on (in this case <code>DBN</code>) will become the index, and will no longer appear as a column in the data itself. To undo this change and keep DBN as a column, we'll need to use <code>pandas.DataFrame.reset_index()</code>. This method will reset the index to a list of integers and make DBN a column again.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [20]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">class_size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">class_size</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">groupby</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'DBN'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">class_size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">class_size</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">agg</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">numpy</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">class_size</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">class_size</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">reset_index</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'class_size'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">class_size</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'class_size'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[20]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="-4.3-Condensing-the-Demographics-Data-Set"><a name="4.3" /> 4.3 Condensing the Demographics Data Set<a class="anchor-link" href="#-4.3-Condensing-the-Demographics-Data-Set">¶</a></h3><p>Now that we've finished condensing <code>class_size</code>, let's condense <code>demographics</code>. The first few rows look like this:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [21]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'demographics'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">())</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In this case, the only column that prevents a given <code>DBN</code> from being unique is <code>schoolyear</code>. We only want to select rows where <code>schoolyear</code> is <code>20112012</code>. This will give us the most recent year of data, and also match our SAT results data.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [24]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">DM</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'demographics'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">DM</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">DM</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">DM</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'schoolyear'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">==</span><span class="mi">20112012</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'demographics'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">DM</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'demographics'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[24]:</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The <code>Demographic</code> and <code>Cohort</code> columns are what prevent <code>DBN</code> from being unique in the <code>graduation</code> data. A <code>Cohort</code> appears to refer to the year the data represents, and the <code>Demographic</code> appears to refer to a specific demographic group. In this case, we want to pick data from the most recent <code>Cohort</code> available, which is <code>2006</code>. We also want data from the full cohort, so we'll only pick rows where <code>Demographic</code> is <code>Total Cohort</code>.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [22]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">GD</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'graduation'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">GD</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">GD</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">GD</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Cohort'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s1">'2006'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">GD</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">GD</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">GD</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Demographic'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s1">'Total Cohort'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'graduation'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">GD</span>
<span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'graduation'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="-4.5-Converting-AP-Test-Scores"><a name="4.5" /> 4.5 Converting AP Test Scores<a class="anchor-link" href="#-4.5-Converting-AP-Test-Scores">¶</a></h3><p>We're almost ready to combine all of the data sets. The only remaining thing to do is convert the Advanced Placement (AP) test scores from strings to numeric values. High school students take the AP exams before applying to college. There are several AP exams, each corresponding to a school subject. High school students who earn high scores may receive college credit.</p>
<p>AP exams have a <code>1</code> to <code>5</code> scale; <code>3</code> or higher is a passing score. Many high school students take AP exams -- particularly those who attend academically challenging institutions. AP exams are much more rare in schools that lack funding or academic rigor.</p>
<p>It will be interesting to find out whether AP exam scores are correlated with SAT scores across high schools. To determine this, we'll need to convert the AP exam scores in the <code>ap_2010</code> data set to numeric values first.</p>
<p>There are three columns we'll need to convert:</p>
<ul>
<li>AP Test Takers</li>
<li>Total Exams Taken</li>
<li>Number of Exams with scores 3, 4 or 5</li>
</ul>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [25]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">cols</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'AP Test Takers '</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Total Exams Taken'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Number of Exams with scores 3 4 or 5'</span><span class="p">]</span>

<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">cols</span><span class="p">:</span>
    <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ap_2010'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">to_numeric</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ap_2010'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">errors</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'coerce'</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'-----'</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ap_2010'</span><span class="p">][</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">dtypes</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>-----
AP Test Takers 
float64
-----
Total Exams Taken
float64
-----
Number of Exams with scores 3 4 or 5
float64
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="-4.6-Performing-the-Left-Joins"><a name="4.6" /> 4.6 Performing the Left Joins<a class="anchor-link" href="#-4.6-Performing-the-Left-Joins">¶</a></h3><p>Both the <code>ap_2010</code> and the graduation data sets have many missing <code>DBN</code> values, so we'll use a <code>left</code> join when we merge the <code>sat_results</code> data set with them. Because we're using a <code>left</code> join, our final dataframe will have all of the same <code>DBN</code> values as the original <code>sat_results</code> dataframe.</p>
<p>We'll need to use the pandas <code>df.merge()</code> method to merge dataframes. The "left" dataframe is the one we call the method on, and the "right" dataframe is the one we pass into <code>df.merge()</code>.</p>
<p>Because we're using the <code>DBN</code> column to join the dataframes, we'll need to specify the keyword argument <code>on="DBN"</code> when calling <code>pandas.DataFrame.merge()</code>.</p>
<p>First, we'll assign <code>data["sat_results"]</code> to the variable <code>combined</code>. Then, we'll merge all of the other dataframes with combined. When we're finished, combined will have all of the columns from all of the data sets.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [26]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">combined</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s2">"sat_results"</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">combined</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">merge</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'ap_2010'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">how</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'left'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">on</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'DBN'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">combined</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">merge</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'graduation'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">how</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'left'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">on</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'DBN'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[26]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>
<style scoped>
    .dataframe tbody tr th:only-of-type {
        vertical-align: middle;
    }

    .dataframe tbody tr th {
        vertical-align: top;
    }

    .dataframe thead th {
        text-align: right;
    }
</style>
<table border="1" class="dataframe">
  <thead>
    <tr style="text-align: right;">
      <th></th>
      <th>DBN</th>
      <th>SCHOOL NAME</th>
      <th>Num of SAT Test Takers</th>
      <th>SAT Critical Reading Avg. Score</th>
      <th>SAT Math Avg. Score</th>
      <th>SAT Writing Avg. Score</th>
      <th>sat_score</th>
      <th>SchoolName</th>
      <th>AP Test Takers</th>
      <th>Total Exams Taken</th>
      <th>...</th>
      <th>Regents w/o Advanced - n</th>
      <th>Regents w/o Advanced - % of cohort</th>
      <th>Regents w/o Advanced - % of grads</th>
      <th>Local - n</th>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="-4.7-Performing-the-Inner-Joins"><a name="4.7" /> 4.7 Performing the Inner Joins<a class="anchor-link" href="#-4.7-Performing-the-Inner-Joins">¶</a></h3><p>Now that we've performed the <code>left</code> joins, we still have to merge <code>class_size</code>, <code>demographics</code>, <code>survey</code>, and <code>hs_directory</code> into <code>combined</code>. Because these files contain information that's more valuable to our analysis and also have fewer missing <code>DBN</code> values, we'll use the <code>inner</code> join type.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [27]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">combined</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">merge</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'class_size'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">how</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'inner'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">on</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'DBN'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">combined</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">merge</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'demographics'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">how</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'inner'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">on</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'DBN'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">combined</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">merge</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'survey'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">how</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'inner'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">on</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'DBN'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">combined</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">merge</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">data</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'hs_directory'</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">how</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'inner'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">on</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'DBN'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="-5.-Filling-in-Missing-Values"><a name="5" /> 5. Filling in Missing Values<a class="anchor-link" href="#-5.-Filling-in-Missing-Values">¶</a></h2><hr>
<p>You may have noticed that the <code>inner</code> joins resulted in <code>116</code> fewer rows in <code>sat_results</code>. This is because pandas couldn't find the <code>DBN</code> values that existed in <code>sat_results</code> in the other data sets. While this is worth investigating, we're currently looking for high-level correlations, so we don't need to dive into which DBNs are missing.</p>
<p>You may also have noticed that we now have many columns with null (<code>NaN</code>) values. This is because we chose to do <code>left</code> joins, where some columns may not have had data. The data set also had some missing values to begin with. If we hadn't performed a <code>left</code> join, all of the rows with missing data would have been lost in the merge process, which wouldn't have left us with many high schools in our data set.</p>
<p>There are several ways to handle missing data, and we'll cover them in more detail later on. For now, we'll just fill in the missing values with the overall mean for the column.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [28]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">means</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">combined</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fillna</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">means</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">combined</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fillna</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">isna</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[28]:</div>
