</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="-6.-Testing-the-Dataset-with-Descriptive-Statistics"><a name="6" /> 6. Testing the Dataset with Descriptive Statistics<a class="anchor-link" href="#-6.-Testing-the-Dataset-with-Descriptive-Statistics">¶</a></h2><hr>
<p>We've finished cleaning and combining our data! We now have a clean data set on which we can base our analysis. Mapping the statistics out on a school district level might be an interesting way to analyze them. Adding a column to the data set that specifies the school district will help us accomplish this.</p>
<p>The school district is just the first two characters of the <code>DBN</code>. We can apply a function over the <code>DBN</code> column of <code>combined</code> that pulls out the first two letters.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [29]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">two_char</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">row</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">school_dist</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="nb">str</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">row</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">school_dist</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">school_dist</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">]</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">school_dist</span>

<span class="n">combined</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'school_dist'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">combined</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'DBN'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">apply</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">two_char</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">combined</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'school_dist'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[29]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>0    01
1    01
2    01
3    01
4    01
Name: school_dist, dtype: object</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="-6.1-Exploring-SAT-score-and-Survey-Answer-Correlations"><a name="6.1" /> 6.1 Exploring SAT-score and Survey Answer Correlations<a class="anchor-link" href="#-6.1-Exploring-SAT-score-and-Survey-Answer-Correlations">¶</a></h3><p>The first thing we'll do is find any correlations between any of the columns and sat_score. This will help us determine which columns might be interesting to plot out or investigate further.</p>
<p>Correlations tell us how closely related two columns are. We'll be using the r value, also called Pearson's correlation coefficient, which measures how closely two sequences of numbers are correlated.</p>
<p>We will only be touching lightly on correlations without investigating any signifiance. In general, r values above <code>.25</code> or below <code>-.25</code> are enough to qualify a correlation as interesting. An r value isn't perfect, and doesn't indicate that there's a correlation -- just the possiblity of one.</p>
<p>Let's take a closer look at how the survey results correlates with the SAT-score.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [31]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">correlations</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corr</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">correlations</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">correlations</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sat_score'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">correlations</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">correlations</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="s2">"rr_s"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"rr_t"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"rr_p"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"N_s"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"N_t"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"N_p"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"saf_p_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"com_p_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"eng_p_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"aca_p_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"saf_t_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"com_t_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"eng_t_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"aca_t_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"saf_s_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"com_s_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"eng_s_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"aca_s_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"saf_tot_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"com_tot_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"eng_tot_11"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"aca_tot_11"</span><span class="p">]]</span>
<span class="n">correlations</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Correlations between SAT-score and Survey Variables'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">figsize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">16</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">the_line</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">axhline</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.25</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'0.25 correlation point'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linestyle</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'--'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">axhline</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'black'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ylabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Correlation Coefficient'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">legend</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">handles</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">the_line</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">show</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The bar plot outlines some very interesting patterns. First and foremost, there is not any noteworthy negative correlations. However, some positive correlations can be noticed:</p>
<ul>
<li>Number of student respondents, teacher respondents and parent respondents (<code>N_s</code>, <code>N_t</code> and <code>N_p</code>)</li>
<li>Safety and Respect score based on teacher responses, student responses and total score (<code>saf_t_11</code>, <code>saf_s_11</code> and <code>saf_tot_11</code>)</li>
<li>Academic expectations score based on student responses (<code>aca_s_11</code>)</li>
</ul>
<p>A <strong>higher number of survey respondents</strong> is correlated with a higher SAT-score. This observation is a bit challenging to explain, but it may suggest that a community with a higher response reflects a general greater engagement attitude in various school tasks.</p>
<p>If we move to the next interesting observation, we will see that a <strong>higher reported safety and respect score</strong> from both teachers and students correlates with a higher SAT-score. This strongly suggest that an environment where safety and respect are prioritized and maintained, leads to students accomplishing better SAT-scores.</p>
<p>Finally, a higher degree of <strong>academic expectation score</strong> is also correlated with a higher SAT-score. It may not be surprising, as this indicates when students have a higher expectations from themselves, it also results in greater SAT-scores. Interestingly, the academic expectations score from parents does not seem to have any noteworthy effect.</p>
<h3 id="-6.2-Exploring-Races-and-SAT-Scores"><a name="6.2" /> 6.2 Exploring Races and SAT-Scores<a class="anchor-link" href="#-6.2-Exploring-Races-and-SAT-Scores">¶</a></h3><p>Let's utilize other parts of the merged dataset by turning our focus on the demographics. More specifically, we can investigate if there is any correlation between the races and obtaining a high SAT-score.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [30]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">correlations</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corr</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">correlations</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">correlations</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sat_score'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">correlations</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">correlations</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="s2">"white_per"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"asian_per"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"black_per"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"hispanic_per"</span><span class="p">]]</span>
<span class="n">correlations</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Correlations between SAT-score and Four Different Races'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">figsize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">16</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">the_line1</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">axhline</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.25</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'0.25 correlation point'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linestyle</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'--'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'green'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">the_line2</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">axhline</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mf">0.25</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'-0.25 correlation point'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linestyle</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'--'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'orange'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">axhline</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ylabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Correlation Coefficient'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xlabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Races'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">legend</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">handles</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">the_line1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">the_line2</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">show</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Surprisingly, the bar plot illustrates a strong correlation for each race and the SAT-score:</p>
<ul>
<li>Schools with a higher percentage of white and asian students generally have a higher SAT-score</li>
<li>schools with a higher percentage of black and hispanic students generally have a lower SAT-score</li>
</ul>
<p>It can be difficult to interpret this result as there would be numerous factors behind this pattern. I will suggest digging into the Hispanic correlation by creating a scatter-plot.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [33]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">x</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'hispanic_per'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'sat_score'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">figsize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">16</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Correlations between percentage of hispanic students and SAT-Scores'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ylabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'SAT-Score'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xlabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Percentage of Students in a High School which are Hispanic'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">show</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The scatter-plot above supports the pattern we observed in the previous bar-plot. The plot indicate a trend that the lower the percentage of hispanic students, the higher the SAT-Score.</p>
<h3 id="-6.3-Explore-Gender-and-SAT-Scores"><a name="6.3" /> 6.3 Explore Gender and SAT-Scores<a class="anchor-link" href="#-6.3-Explore-Gender-and-SAT-Scores">¶</a></h3><p>Let's wrap up this small analytics section by investigating the correlations between the genders and the SAT-Score.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [32]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">correlations</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">combined</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">corr</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">correlations</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">correlations</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'sat_score'</span><span class="p">]</span>
<span class="n">correlations</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">correlations</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">loc</span><span class="p">[[</span><span class="s2">"male_per"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s2">"female_per"</span><span class="p">]]</span>
<span class="n">correlations</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s1">'Correlations between SAT-score and Gender'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">figsize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">16</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">axhline</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ylabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Correlation Coefficient'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xlabel</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Gender'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">legend</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">handles</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">the_line1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">the_line2</span><span class="p">])</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">show</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,
"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>There is a slight difference between the genders. Females tend to have a higher SAT-score and vice versa. However, it is important to notice that the correlations are only 0.11 for both genders which indicates a weak correlation. Thus, this suggests that it does not make a difference for a high school to have more of one gender.</p>
<h2 id="-7.-Conclusion"><a name="7" /> 7. Conclusion<a class="anchor-link" href="#-7.-Conclusion">¶</a></h2><p>The goals of this project were to demonstrate process of importing several datasets, prepare the datasets for merging, merge the data sets and perform descriptive statistics with the combined data. While the descriptive statistics showed some interesting findings, the project was only to demonstrate skills in the data cleaning and wrangling process.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>

    mathjaxscript[(window.opera ? "innerHTML" : "text")] =
        "MathJax.Hub.Config({" +

entry.title: Cleaning the Star Wars
entry.content:
<style type="text/css">/*!
*
* IPython notebook

*/
/* CSS font colors for translated ANSI escape sequences */
/* The color values are a mix of
   http://www.xcolors.net/dl/baskerville-ivorylight and
   http://www.xcolors.net/dl/euphrasia */
.ansi-black-fg {
  color: #3E424D;
}
.ansi-black-bg {
  background-color: #3E424D;
}
.ansi-black-intense-fg {
  color: #282C36;
}
.ansi-black-intense-bg {
  background-color: #282C36;
}
.ansi-red-fg {
  color: #E75C58;
}
.ansi-red-bg {
  background-color: #E75C58;
}
.ansi-red-intense-fg {
  color: #B22B31;
}
.ansi-red-intense-bg {
  background-color: #B22B31;
}
.ansi-green-fg {
  color: #00A250;
}
.ansi-green-bg {
  background-color: #00A250;
}
.ansi-green-intense-fg {
  color: #007427;
}
.ansi-green-intense-bg {
  background-color: #007427;
}
.ansi-yellow-fg {
  color: #DDB62B;
}
.ansi-yellow-bg {
  background-color: #DDB62B;
}
.ansi-yellow-intense-fg {
  color: #B27D12;
}
.ansi-yellow-intense-bg {
  background-color: #B27D12;
}
.ansi-blue-fg {
  color: #208FFB;
}
.ansi-blue-bg {
  background-color: #208FFB;
}
.ansi-blue-intense-fg {
  color: #0065CA;
}
.ansi-blue-intense-bg {
  background-color: #0065CA;
}
.ansi-magenta-fg {
  color: #D160C4;
}
.ansi-magenta-bg {
  background-color: #D160C4;
}
.ansi-magenta-intense-fg {
  color: #A03196;
}
.ansi-magenta-intense-bg {
  background-color: #A03196;
}
.ansi-cyan-fg {
  color: #60C6C8;
}
.ansi-cyan-bg {
  background-color: #60C6C8;
}
.ansi-cyan-intense-fg {
  color: #258F8F;
}
.ansi-cyan-intense-bg {
  background-color: #258F8F;
}
.ansi-white-fg {
  color: #C5C1B4;
}
.ansi-white-bg {
  background-color: #C5C1B4;
}
.ansi-white-intense-fg {
  color: #A1A6B2;
}
.ansi-white-intense-bg {
  background-color: #A1A6B2;
}
.ansi-default-inverse-fg {

}
.ansi-default-inverse-bg {
  background-color: #000000;
}
.ansi-bold {
  font-weight: bold;
}
.ansi-underline {

}
/* The following styles are deprecated an will be removed in a future version */
.ansibold {
  font-weight: bold;
}
.ansi-inverse {
  outline: 0.5px dotted;
}
/* use dark versions for foreground, to improve visibility */
.ansiblack {

}
.ansired {

}
.ansigreen {

}

}

}

}

}

}
/* and light for background, for the same reason */
.ansibgblack {

}
.ansibgred {
  background-color: red;
}
.ansibggreen {
  background-color: green;
}
.ansibgyellow {
  background-color: yellow;
}
.ansibgblue {
  background-color: blue;
}
.ansibgpurple {
  background-color: magenta;
}
.ansibgcyan {
  background-color: cyan;
}
.ansibggray {
  background-color: gray;
}
div.cell {
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  border-radius: 2px;
  box-sizing: border-box;
  -moz-box-sizing: border-box;
  -webkit-box-sizing: border-box;
  border-width: 1px;
  border-style: solid;
  border-color: transparent;
  width: 100%;
  padding: 5px;
  /* This acts as a spacer between cells, that is outside the border */
  margin: 0px;
  outline: none;
  position: relative;
  overflow: visible;
}
div.cell:before {
  position: absolute;
  display: block;
  top: -1px;
  left: -1px;
  width: 5px;
  height: calc(100% +  2px);
  content: '';
  background: transparent;
}
div.cell.jupyter-soft-selected {
  border-left-color: #E3F2FD;
  border-left-width: 1px;
  padding-left: 5px;
  border-right-color: #E3F2FD;
  border-right-width: 1px;
  background: #E3F2FD;
}
@media print {
  div.cell.jupyter-soft-selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
div.cell.selected,
div.cell.selected.jupyter-soft-selected {
  border-color: #ababab;
}
div.cell.selected:before,
div.cell.selected.jupyter-soft-selected:before {
  position: absolute;
  display: block;
  top: -1px;
  left: -1px;
  width: 5px;
  height: calc(100% +  2px);
  content: '';
  background: #42A5F5;
}
@media print {
  div.cell.selected,
  div.cell.selected.jupyter-soft-selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
.edit_mode div.cell.selected {
  border-color: #66BB6A;
}
.edit_mode div.cell.selected:before {
  position: absolute;
  display: block;
  top: -1px;
  left: -1px;
  width: 5px;
  height: calc(100% +  2px);
  content: '';
  background: #66BB6A;
}
@media print {
  .edit_mode div.cell.selected {
    border-color: transparent;
  }
}
.prompt {
  /* This needs to be wide enough for 3 digit prompt numbers: In[100]: */
  min-width: 14ex;
  /* This padding is tuned to match the padding on the CodeMirror editor. */
  padding: 0.4em;
  margin: 0px;
  font-family: monospace;
  text-align: right;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Don't highlight prompt number selection */
  -webkit-touch-callout: none;
  -webkit-user-select: none;
  -khtml-user-select: none;
  -moz-user-select: none;
  -ms-user-select: none;
  user-select: none;
  /* Use default cursor */
  cursor: default;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  .prompt {
    text-align: left;
  }
}
div.inner_cell {
  min-width: 0;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  /* Old browsers */
  -webkit-box-flex: 1;
  -moz-box-flex: 1;
  box-flex: 1;
  /* Modern browsers */
  flex: 1;
}
/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_area {
  border: 1px solid #cfcfcf;
  border-radius: 2px;
  background: #f7f7f7;
  line-height: 1.21429em;
}
/* This is needed so that empty prompt areas can collapse to zero height when there
   is no content in the output_subarea and the prompt. The main purpose of this is
   to make sure that empty JavaScript output_subareas have no height. */
div.prompt:empty {
  padding-top: 0;
  padding-bottom: 0;
}
div.unrecognized_cell {
  padding: 5px 5px 5px 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: horizontal;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell {
  border-radius: 2px;
  padding: 5px;
  font-weight: bold;
  color: red;
  border: 1px solid #cfcfcf;
  background: #eaeaea;
}
div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell a {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
div.unrecognized_cell .inner_cell a:hover {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  div.unrecognized_cell > div.prompt {
    display: none;
  }
}
div.code_cell {
  /* avoid page breaking on code cells when printing */
}
@media print {
  div.code_cell {
    page-break-inside: avoid;
  }
}
/* any special styling for code cells that are currently running goes here */
div.input {
  page-break-inside: avoid;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: horizontal;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  align-items: stretch;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  div.input {
    /* Old browsers */
    display: -webkit-box;
    -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
    -webkit-box-align: stretch;
    display: -moz-box;
    -moz-box-orient: vertical;
    -moz-box-align: stretch;
    display: box;
    box-orient: vertical;
    box-align: stretch;
    /* Modern browsers */
    display: flex;
    flex-direction: column;
    align-items: stretch;
  }
}
/* input_area and input_prompt must match in top border and margin for alignment */
div.input_prompt {
  color: #303F9F;
  border-top: 1px solid transparent;
}
div.input_area > div.highlight {
  margin: 0.4em;
  border: none;
  padding: 0px;
  background-color: transparent;
}
div.input_area > div.highlight > pre {
  margin: 0px;
  border: none;
  padding: 0px;
  background-color: transparent;
}
/* The following gets added to the <head> if it is detected that the user has a
 * monospace font with inconsistent normal/bold/italic height.  See
 * notebookmain.js.  Such fonts will have keywords vertically offset with
 * respect to the rest of the text.  The user should select a better font.
 * See: https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/1503
 *
 * .CodeMirror span {
 *      vertical-align: bottom;
 * }
 */
.CodeMirror {
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  /* Changed from 1em to our global default */
  font-size: 14px;
  height: auto;
  /* Changed to auto to autogrow */
  background: none;
  /* Changed from white to allow our bg to show through */
}
.CodeMirror-scroll {
  /*  The CodeMirror docs are a bit fuzzy on if overflow-y should be hidden or visible.*/
  /*  We have found that if it is visible, vertical scrollbars appear with font size changes.*/
  overflow-y: hidden;
  overflow-x: auto;
}
.CodeMirror-lines {
  /* In CM2, this used to be 0.4em, but in CM3 it went to 4px. We need the em value because */
  /* we have set a different line-height and want this to scale with that. */
  /* Note that this should set vertical padding only, since CodeMirror assumes
       that horizontal padding will be set on CodeMirror pre */
  padding: 0.4em 0;
}
.CodeMirror-linenumber {
  padding: 0 8px 0 4px;
}
.CodeMirror-gutters {
  border-bottom-left-radius: 2px;
  border-top-left-radius: 2px;
}
.CodeMirror pre {
  /* In CM3 this went to 4px from 0 in CM2. This sets horizontal padding only,
    use .CodeMirror-lines for vertical */
  padding: 0 0.4em;
  border: 0;
  border-radius: 0;
}
.CodeMirror-cursor {
  border-left: 1.4px solid black;
}
@media screen and (min-width: 2138px) and (max-width: 4319px) {
  .CodeMirror-cursor {
    border-left: 2px solid black;
  }
}
@media screen and (min-width: 4320px) {
  .CodeMirror-cursor {
    border-left: 4px solid black;
  }
}

div.output_wrapper {
  /* this position must be relative to enable descendents to be absolute within it */
  position: relative;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
  z-index: 1;
}
/* class for the output area when it should be height-limited */
div.output_scroll {
  /* ideally, this would be max-height, but FF barfs all over that */
  height: 24em;
  /* FF needs this *and the wrapper* to specify full width, or it will shrinkwrap */
  width: 100%;
  overflow: auto;
  border-radius: 2px;
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  box-shadow: inset 0 2px 8px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.8);
  display: block;
}
/* output div while it is collapsed */
div.output_collapsed {
  margin: 0px;
  padding: 0px;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay {
  height: 100%;
  padding: 0px 0.4em;
  position: absolute;
  border-radius: 2px;
}
div.out_prompt_overlay:hover {
  /* use inner shadow to get border that is computed the same on WebKit/FF */
  -webkit-box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  box-shadow: inset 0 0 1px #000;
  background: rgba(240, 240, 240, 0.5);
}
div.output_prompt {
  color: #D84315;
}
/* This class is the outer container of all output sections. */
div.output_area {
  padding: 0px;
  page-break-inside: avoid;
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: horizontal;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: horizontal;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: horizontal;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: row;
  align-items: stretch;
}
div.output_area .MathJax_Display {
  text-align: left !important;
}
div.output_area 
div.output_area 
div.output_area img,
div.output_area svg {
  max-width: 100%;
  height: auto;
}
div.output_area img.unconfined,
div.output_area svg.unconfined {
  max-width: none;
}
div.output_area .mglyph > img {
  max-width: none;
}
/* This is needed to protect the pre formating from global settings such
   as that of bootstrap */
.output {
  /* Old browsers */
  display: -webkit-box;
  -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
  -webkit-box-align: stretch;
  display: -moz-box;
  -moz-box-orient: vertical;
  -moz-box-align: stretch;
  display: box;
  box-orient: vertical;
  box-align: stretch;
  /* Modern browsers */
  display: flex;
  flex-direction: column;
  align-items: stretch;
}
@media (max-width: 540px) {
  div.output_area {
    /* Old browsers */
    display: -webkit-box;
    -webkit-box-orient: vertical;
    -webkit-box-align: stretch;
    display: -moz-box;
    -moz-box-orient: vertical;
    -moz-box-align: stretch;
    display: box;
    box-orient: vertical;
    box-align: stretch;
    /* Modern browsers */
    display: flex;
    flex-direction: column;
    align-items: stretch;
  }
}
div.output_area pre {
  margin: 0;
  padding: 1px 0 1px 0;
  border: 0;
  vertical-align: baseline;
  color: black;
  background-color: transparent;
  border-radius: 0;
}
/* This class is for the output subarea inside the output_area and after
   the prompt div. */
div.output_subarea {
  overflow-x: auto;
  padding: 0.4em;
  /* Old browsers */
  -webkit-box-flex: 1;
  -moz-box-flex: 1;
  box-flex: 1;
  /* Modern browsers */
  flex: 1;
  max-width: calc(100% - 14ex);
}
div.output_scroll div.output_subarea {
  overflow-x: visible;
}
/* The rest of the output_* classes are for special styling of the different
   output types */
/* all text output has this class: */
div.output_text {
  text-align: left;
  color: #000;
  /* This has to match that of the the CodeMirror class line-height below */
  line-height: 1.21429em;
}
/* stdout/stderr are 'text' as well as 'stream', but execute_result/error are *not* streams */
div.output_stderr {
  background: #fdd;
  /* very light red background for stderr */
}
div.output_latex {
  text-align: left;
}
/* Empty output_javascript divs should have no height */
div.output_javascript:empty {
  padding: 0;
}
.js-error {
  color: darkred;
}
/* raw_input styles */
div.raw_input_container {
  line-height: 1.21429em;
  padding-top: 5px;
}
pre.raw_input_prompt {
  /* nothing needed here. */
}
input.raw_input {
  font-family: monospace;
  font-size: inherit;
  color: inherit;
  width: auto;
  /* make sure input baseline aligns with prompt */
  vertical-align: baseline;
  /* padding + margin = 0.5em between prompt and cursor */
  padding: 0em 0.25em;
  margin: 0em 0.25em;
}
input.raw_input:focus {
  box-shadow: none;
}
p.p-space {
  margin-bottom: 10px;
}
div.output_unrecognized {
  padding: 5px;
  font-weight: bold;
  color: red;
}
div.output_unrecognized a {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
div.output_unrecognized a:hover {
  color: inherit;
  text-decoration: none;
}
.rendered_html {
  color: #000;
  /* any extras will just be numbers: */
}



.rendered_html :link {
  text-decoration: underline;
}
.rendered_html :visited {
  text-decoration: underline;
}






.rendered_html h1:first-child {
  margin-top: 0.538em;
}
.rendered_html h2:first-child {
  margin-top: 0.636em;
}
.rendered_html h3:first-child {
  margin-top: 0.777em;
}
.rendered_html h4:first-child {
  margin-top: 1em;
}
.rendered_html h5:first-child {
  margin-top: 1em;
}
.rendered_html h6:first-child {
  margin-top: 1em;
}
.rendered_html ul:not(.list-inline),
.rendered_html ol:not(.list-inline) {
  padding-left: 2em;
}








.rendered_html * + ul {
  margin-top: 1em;
}
.rendered_html * + ol {
  margin-top: 1em;
}





.rendered_html pre,




.rendered_html tr,
.rendered_html th,


.rendered_html tbody tr:nth-child(odd) {
  background: #f5f5f5;
}
.rendered_html tbody tr:hover {
  background: rgba(66, 165, 245, 0.2);
}
.rendered_html * + table {
  margin-top: 1em;
}

.rendered_html * + p {
  margin-top: 1em;
}

.rendered_html * + img {
  margin-top: 1em;
}
.rendered_html img,

.rendered_html img.unconfined,


.rendered_html * + .alert {
  margin-top: 1em;
}

  color: #000;

  -moz-box-sizing: border-box;
  -webkit-box-sizing: border-box;

  padding: 0px 20px;
  visibility: hidden;
}
h1:hover .anchor-link,

h3:hover .anchor-link,
h4:hover .anchor-link,
h5:hover .anchor-link,

  visibility: visible;
}
.text_cell.rendered .input_area {

.text_cell.rendered

.text_cell.rendered .rendered_html th,
.text_cell.rendered 
.text_cell.unrendered .text_cell_render {

.cm-header-1,
.cm-header-2,
.cm-header-3,
.cm-header-4,

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h1 id="Cleaning-the-Star-Wars-Data">Cleaning the Star Wars Data<a class="anchor-link" href="#Cleaning-the-Star-Wars-Data">¶</a></h1><h2 id="An-Example-in:-Data-Cleaning-&-Wrangling"><em>An Example in: Data Cleaning & Wrangling</em><a class="anchor-link" href="#An-Example-in:-Data-Cleaning-&-Wrangling">¶</a></h2><p><img src="../portfolio/Data/star_wars/star_wars_cleaning3.jpg" alt="Cleaning Star Wars"></p>
<p>Data cleansing is a subprocess of the data science process that focuses on removing errors in your data, so your data becomes a true and consistent representation of the processes it originates from. The entire process of cleaning, transforming and combining data is often said to represent 80% of data science projects.</p>
<p>I will be demonstrating the most basic and common task in this minor project. More advanced features will not be explained in this project, such as:</p>
<ul>
<li>detecting and handling outliers, </li>
<li>in-depth solutions for missing data (like multiple imputations) </li>
<li>ensuring dates are correct and homogeneous.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<h2 id="Table-of-Contents"><em>Table of Contents</em><a class="anchor-link" href="#Table-of-Contents">¶</a></h2><ul>
<li><a href="#1">1. Introduction</a></li>
<li><a href="#2">2. Importing the Data</a></li>
<li><a href="#3">3. Exploring the Columns and Rows</a></li>
<li><a href="#4">4. Renaming the Columns</a></li>
<li><a href="#5">5. Removing Missing Data</a></li>
<li><a href="#6">6. Mapping Values</a></li>
<li><a href="#7">7. Change Columns Type</a></li>
<li><a href="#8">8. Descriptive Statistics</a></li>
</ul>
<h2 id="-1.-Introduction"><a name="1" /> 1. Introduction<a class="anchor-link" href="#-1.-Introduction">¶</a></h2><p>While waiting for <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_Wars:_The_Force_Awakens">Star Wars: The Force Awakens</a> to come out, the team at <a href="https://fivethirtyeight.com/">FiveThirtyEight</a> became interested in answering some questions about Star Wars fans. In particular, they wondered: <strong>does the rest of America realize that â€œThe Empire Strikes Backâ€ is clearly the best of the bunch?</strong></p>
<p>The team needed to collect data addressing this question. To do this, they surveyed Star Wars fans using the online tool SurveyMonkey. They received 835 total responses, which you can explore for yourself from <a href="https://github.com/fivethirtyeight/data/tree/master/star-wars-survey">their GitHub repository.</a></p>
<p>In this project, I will provide an example of cleaning and slightly analyzing the data on the Star Wars movies.</p>
<h2 id="-2.-Importing-the-Data"><a name="2" /> 2. Importing the Data<a class="anchor-link" href="#-2.-Importing-the-Data">¶</a></h2><p>We will be using the <strong><em>Pandas</em></strong> library as the main tool for getting familiarized and tidying the data. Fortunately, the Pandas library also provides excellent data importing options with various essential parameters (e.g. the type of encoding). The following code will read the data from a <strong><em>"Comma-separated values"</em></strong> (CSV) file into a pandas dataframe:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [1]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">pandas</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">pd</span>
<span class="n">star_wars</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">read_csv</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s2">"Data/star_wars/star_wars.csv"</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">encoding</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"ISO-8859-1"</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We need to specify an <strong><em>encoding</em></strong> because the data set has some characters that aren't in Python's default <strong><em>utf-8</em></strong> encoding.</p>
<h2 id="-3.-Exploring-the-Columns-and-Rows"><a name="3" /> 3. Exploring the Columns and Rows<a class="anchor-link" href="#-3.-Exploring-the-Columns-and-Rows">¶</a></h2><p>As we now have all the data in the <strong><em>star_wars</em></strong> dataframe, letâ€™s begin to explore the data by first getting an overview of the column names, and the number of columns and rows. We will obtain this information by using the <strong><em>info</em></strong> function in the Pandas library.</p>
<p>Furthermore, we will also be using the <strong><em>head</em></strong> and <strong><em>tail</em></strong> function to get some insight about the first 5 and last 5 rows in the dataframe.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">info</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">head</span><span class="p">()</span>

      <td>Very favorably</td>
      <td>Han</td>
      <td>No</td>
      <td>NaN</td>

    <tr>
      <th>1186</th>
      <td>3.288373e+09</td>

      <td>No</td>

      <td>Star Wars: Episode II  Attack of the Clones</td>

</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The <strong><em>info</em></strong> function in combination with <strong><em>head</em></strong> and <strong><em>tail</em></strong> are incredibly useful as it has now provided us with the following information:</p>
<ul>
<li>There are <strong>38 columns</strong></li>
<li>There are <strong>1187 rows</strong> (including header)</li>
<li>There is only 1 <strong><em>float</em></strong> (ID column) and the remaining columns are the <strong><em>object</em></strong> type</li>
<li>There is various amount of missing values in each column</li>
<li>The naming of the columns is messy with many <strong>Unnamed</strong> columns and a few very long column names</li>
</ul>
<p>Based on this exploration we will need to investigate the naming of the columns and the missing values. We will start off by digging into the renaming part, so it will be more intuitive to work with the dataframe.</p>
<h2 id="-4.-Renaming-the-Columns"><a name="4" /> 4. Renaming the Columns<a class="anchor-link" href="#-4.-Renaming-the-Columns">¶</a></h2><p>In order to rename the columns, we will need to know specifically what each column represents. The <strong><em>head</em></strong> and <strong><em>tail</em></strong> function provided some insight to this.</p>
<p>The data has several columns, including:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong><em>RespondentID</em></strong> - An anonymized ID for the respondent (person taking the survey)</li>
<li><strong><em>Gender</em></strong> - The respondent's gender</li>
<li><strong><em>Age</em></strong> - The respondent's age</li>
<li><strong><em>Household Income</em></strong> - The respondent's income</li>
<li><strong><em>Education</em></strong> - The respondent's education level</li>
<li><strong><em>Location (Census Region)</em></strong> - The respondent's location</li>
<li><strong><em>Do you consider yourself to be a fan of the Star Wars film franchise?</em></strong> - Has a Yes or No response</li>
<li><strong><em>Have you seen any of the 6 films in the Star Wars franchise?</em></strong> - Has a Yes or No response</li>
</ul>
<p>There are several other columns containing answers to questions about the Star Wars movies. For some questions, the respondent had to check one or more boxes. This type of data is difficult to represent in columnar format. As a result, many of the columns have been named <strong>unnamed</strong>.</p>
<p>The unnamed columns are basicaly an extension of the question that proceeded a sequence of unnamed columns. To clarify, I will illustrate the first sequence of unnamed columns:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong><em>Which of the following Star Wars films have you seen? Please select all that apply.</em></strong> - Whether or not the respondent saw <em>Star Wars: Episode I The Phantom Menace</em>.</li>
<li><strong><em>Unnamed: 4</em></strong> - Whether or not the respondent saw <em>Star Wars: Episode II Attack of the Clones</em>.</li>
<li><strong><em>Unnamed: 5</em></strong> - Whether or not the respondent saw <em>Star Wars: Episode III Revenge of the Sith</em>.</li>
<li><strong><em>Unnamed: 6</em></strong> - Whether or not the respondent saw <em>Star Wars: Episode IV A New Hope</em>.</li>
<li><strong><em>Unnamed: 7</em></strong> - Whether or not the respondent saw <em>Star Wars: Episode V The Empire Strikes Back</em>.</li>
<li><strong><em>Unnamed: 8</em></strong> - Whether or not the respondent saw <em>Star Wars: Episode VI Return of the Jedi</em>.</li>
</ul>
<p>For each of these columns, if the value in a cell is the name of the movie, that means the respondent saw the movie. If the value is <code>NaN</code>, the respondent either didn't answer or didn't see the movie. We'll assume that they didn't see the movie.</p>
<h3 id="4.1-Renaming-Unnamed-4-8-Columns">4.1 Renaming Unnamed 4-8 Columns<a class="anchor-link" href="#4.1-Renaming-Unnamed-4-8-Columns">¶</a></h3><p>We will start off by renaming these columns to a more understandable naming. We will do this by creating a dictionary which will contain the translation of the new column names. Afterwards we will feed the <strong><em>rename</em></strong> method with the dictionary.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [5]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">new_names</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="s1">'Which of the following Star Wars films have you seen? Please select all that apply.'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'seen_1'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 4'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'seen_2'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 5'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'seen_3'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 6'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'seen_4'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 7'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'seen_5'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 8'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'seen_6'</span><span class="p">}</span>

<span class="n">star_wars</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rename</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">new_names</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iloc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">9</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

<h3 id="4.2-Renaming-Unnamed-10-14-and-16-28-Columns">4.2 Renaming Unnamed 10-14 and 16-28 Columns<a class="anchor-link" href="#4.2-Renaming-Unnamed-10-14-and-16-28-Columns">¶</a></h3><p>The sequence of unnamed 4-8 have successfully been renamed to <strong>seen_x</strong>. <div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [8]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">new_names</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="s1">'Please state whether you view the following characters favorably, unfavorably, or are unfamiliar with him/her.'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Han Solo'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 16'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Luke Skywalker'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 17'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Princess Leia Organa'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 18'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Anakin Skywalker'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 19'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Obi Wan Kenobi'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 20'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Emperor Palpatine'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 21'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Darth Vader'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 22'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Lando Calrissian'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 23'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Boba Fett'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 24'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'C-3P0'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 25'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'R2 D2'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 26'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Jar Jar Binks'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 27'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Padme Amidala'</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s1">'Unnamed: 28'</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="s1">'Yoda'</span><span class="p">}</span>

<span class="n">star_wars</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">rename</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">columns</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="n">new_names</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iloc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">15</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">29</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="4.3-Inspecting-the-Renamed-Columns">4.3 Inspecting the Renamed Columns<a class="anchor-link" href="#4.3-Inspecting-the-Renamed-Columns">¶</a></h3><p>Now that we have renamed all the unnamed columns, lets get an overview of all the names in a list format.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">columns</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[9]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>Index(['RespondentID',

       'Gender', 'Age', 'Household Income', 'Education',
       'Location (Census Region)'],
      dtype='object')</pre>
</div>

<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="-5.-Removing-Missing-Data"><a name="5" /> 5. Removing Missing Data<a class="anchor-link" href="#-5.-Removing-Missing-Data">¶</a></h2><p>The columns have now been renamed to a naming which is more intuitive to understand. Now we will explore the amount of missing data. We can do this by using the <strong><em>isnull</em></strong> in combination with the <strong><em>sum</em></strong> methods.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [11]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">isnull</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[11]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">

rank_6                                                                   350

Princess Leia Organa                                                     355

dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>From this initial inspection, it could seem that there is an unreasonably high amount of missing data. However, we will soon see that this may not be the case for most columns in the dataframe. We will get into this in the next section.</p>
<p>Before we move on, we will need to remove the row with a missing value in the respondentID column.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [12]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">star_wars</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">pd</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">notnull</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'RespondentID'</span><span class="p">])]</span>
<span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'RespondentID'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">isnull</span><span class="p">()</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sum</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[12]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>0</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="-6.-Mapping-Values"><a name="6" /> 6. Mapping Values<a class="anchor-link" href="#-6.-Mapping-Values">¶</a></h2><p>In the previous section we observed a high number of missing values across all columns. But when we begin to investigate this pattern we will see a quite another explanation for the missing values.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [13]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iloc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">9</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[13]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>

</div>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="6.1-Mapping-Yes/No-Columns">6.1 Mapping Yes/No Columns<a class="anchor-link" href="#6.1-Mapping-Yes/No-Columns">¶</a></h3><p>Take a look at the next two columns after RespondentID, which are:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong><em>Have you seen any of the 6 films in the Star Wars franchise?</em></strong></li>
<li><strong><em>Do you consider yourself to be a fan of the Star Wars film franchise?</em></strong></li>
</ul>
<p>Both represent <em>Yes/No</em> questions. They can also be <em>NaN</em> where a respondent chooses not to answer a question. We can use the <em>pandas.Series.value_counts()</em> method on a series to see all the unique values in a column, along with the total number of times each value appears.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [16]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Have you seen any of the 6 films in the Star Wars franchise?'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[16]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>Yes    936
No     250
Name: Have you seen any of the 6 films in the Star Wars franchise?, dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [17]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Do you consider yourself to be a fan of the Star Wars film franchise?'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[17]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>Yes    552
No     284
Name: Do you consider yourself to be a fan of the Star Wars film franchise?, dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Both columns are currently <strong>string types</strong>, because the main values they contain are <em>Yes</em> and <em>No</em>. We can make the data a bit easier to analyze down the road by converting each column to a <em>Boolean</em> having only the values True, False, and NaN. Booleans are easier to work with because we can select the rows that are True or False without having to do a string comparison.</p>
<p>We can use the <strong>pandas.Series.map()</strong> method on series objects to perform the conversion.</p>
<p>As we can see in the first 5 rows of the dataframe, missing values may indicate the answer "no" whereas the name of the star wars movie represents the answer "yes". For the purpose of this project we will assume the missing values in these columns indeed represents the answer "no".</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [18]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">yes_no</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="s2">"Yes"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s2">"No"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">False</span>
<span class="p">}</span>
<span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Have you seen any of the 6 films in the Star Wars franchise?'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Have you seen any of the 6 films in the Star Wars franchise?'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">map</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">yes_no</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Have you seen any of the 6 films in the Star Wars franchise?'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[18]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>True     936
False    250
Name: Have you seen any of the 6 films in the Star Wars franchise?, dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [19]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Do you consider yourself to be a fan of the Star Wars film franchise?'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Do you consider yourself to be a fan of the Star Wars film franchise?'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">map</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">yes_no</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Do you consider yourself to be a fan of the Star Wars film franchise?'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">value_counts</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[19]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>True     552
False    284
Name: Do you consider yourself to be a fan of the Star Wars film franchise?, dtype: int64</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can see the value_counts demonstrated that the 2 columns have indeed been converted to boolean. I will continue to do the same for the 3 remaning yes/no columns in the dataframe.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [20]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Are you familiar with the Expanded Universe?'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Are you familiar with the Expanded Universe?'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">map</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">yes_no</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Do you consider yourself to be a fan of the Expanded Universe???'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Do you consider yourself to be a fan of the Expanded Universe???'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">map</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">yes_no</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Do you consider yourself to be a fan of the Star Trek franchise?'</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="s1">'Do you consider yourself to be a fan of the Star Trek franchise?'</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">map</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">yes_no</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h3 id="6.2-Mapping-Checkbox-Columns">6.2 Mapping Checkbox Columns<a class="anchor-link" href="#6.2-Mapping-Checkbox-Columns">¶</a></h3><p>The next six columns represent a single checkbox question. The respondent checked off a series of boxes in response to the question, <strong><em>Which of the following Star Wars films have you seen? Please select all that apply</em></strong>.</p>
<p>For each of these columns, if the value in a cell is the name of the movie, that means the respondent saw the movie. If the value is <strong><em>NaN</em></strong>, the respondent either didn't answer or didn't see the movie. We'll assume that they didn't see the movie.</p>
<p>We'll need to convert each of these columns to a <strong><em>Boolean</em></strong>. We can convert the values the same way we did earlier, except that we'll need to include the movie title and NaN in the mapping dictionary.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [21]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
<span class="n">true_false</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">{</span>
    <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">NaN</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s2">"Star Wars: Episode I  The Phantom Menace"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s2">"Star Wars: Episode II  Attack of the Clones"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s2">"Star Wars: Episode III  Revenge of the Sith"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s2">"Star Wars: Episode IV  A New Hope"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s2">"Star Wars: Episode V The Empire Strikes Back"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">True</span><span class="p">,</span>
    <span class="s2">"Star Wars: Episode VI Return of the Jedi"</span><span class="p">:</span> <span class="kc">True</span>
<span class="p">}</span>

<span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">i</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="nb">range</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">9</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iloc</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iloc</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="n">i</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">map</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">true_false</span><span class="p">)</span>
    
<span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iloc</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">5</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">9</span><span class="p">]</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[21]:</div>



<div class="output_html rendered_html output_subarea output_execute_result">
<div>

  </tbody>
</table>
</div>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>All the "seen" columns have successfully been mapped to boolean type.</p>
<h2 id="-7.-Change-Columns-Type"><a name="7" /> 7. Change Columns Type<a class="anchor-link" href="#-7.-Change-Columns-Type">¶</a></h2><p>The next six columns ask the respondent to rank the Star Wars movies in order of least favorite to most favorite. 1 means the film was the most favorite, and 6 means it was the least favorite. Each of the following columns can contain the value <strong>1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6</strong> or <strong>NaN</strong>:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>rank_1</strong> - How much the respondent liked <em>Star Wars: Episode I The Phantom Menace</em></li>
<li><strong>rank_2</strong> - How much the respondent liked <em>Star Wars: Episode II Attack of the Clones</em></li>
<li><strong>rank_3</strong> - How much the respondent liked <em>Star Wars: Episode III Revenge of the Sith</em></li>
<li><strong>rank_4</strong> - How much the respondent liked <em>Star Wars: Episode IV A New Hope</em></li>
<li><strong>rank_5</strong> - How much the respondent liked <em>Star Wars: Episode V The Empire Strikes Back</em></li>
<li><strong>rank_6</strong> - How much the respondent liked <em>Star Wars: Episode VI Return of the Jedi</em></li>
</ul>
<p>Fortunately, these columns don't require a lot of cleanup. We'll need to convert each column to a <strong><em>numeric type</em></strong>.</p>
<p>We can do the numeric conversion with the <strong><em>pandas.DataFrame.astype()</em></strong> method on dataframes.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [25]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iloc</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">9</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">15</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">info</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre><class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
Int64Index: 1186 entries, 1 to 1186
Data columns (total 6 columns):
rank_1    835 non-null float64
rank_2    836 non-null float64
rank_3    835 non-null float64
rank_4    836 non-null float64
rank_5    836 non-null float64
rank_6    836 non-null float64
dtypes: float64(6)
memory usage: 64.9 KB
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [24]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">columns</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">9</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">15</span><span class="p">]]</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">columns</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">9</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">15</span><span class="p">]]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">astype</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="nb">float</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [22]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iloc</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">9</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">15</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">info</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre><class 'pandas.core.frame.DataFrame'>
Int64Index: 1186 entries, 1 to 1186

dtypes: object(6)
memory usage: 64.9+ KB
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="-8.-Descriptive-Statistics"><a name="8" /> 8. Descriptive Statistics<a class="anchor-link" href="#-8.-Descriptive-Statistics">¶</a></h2><p>Now that the dataframe has been cleaned up, we can perform a few descriptive statistics. Letâ€™s find the highest-ranked movie. To do this, we will take the mean of each of the ranking columns using the <strong><em>pandas.DataFrame.mean()</em></strong> method on dataframes.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [23]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iloc</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">9</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">15</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[23]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre>Series([], dtype: float64)</pre>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Based on the mean values it may seem the best ranking star wars movie among the responders is <strong><em>"Star Wars: Episode V The Empire Strikes Back"</em></strong> and the least ranked is the <strong><em>"Star Wars: Episode III Revenge of the Sith"</em></strong> (remember lower score is better ranking).</p>
<p>Now letâ€™s make a bar chart to display this difference more visually.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [26]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="o">%</span><span class="k">matplotlib</span> inline
<span class="n">mean_ranking</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">star_wars</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">iloc</span><span class="p">[:,</span><span class="mi">9</span><span class="p">:</span><span class="mi">15</span><span class="p">]</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">()</span>
<span class="n">mean_ranking</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">bar</span><span class="p">()</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[26]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.axes._subplots.AxesSubplot at 0x2720c4acda0></pre>
</div>

</div>
